title: How to Fight Back Against AI Bot Scrapers

rawLines.text: If you like 404 media, you probably have
followed our reporting about how big
tech has made consuming the news a mess.
Social media and search algorithms have
made finding and understanding the news
exhausting. It's tough scrolling through
timelines full of content that have been
reverse engineered to perform well in an
algorithm or that you're only seeing
because of targeted advertising. That's
why I like Ground News, a news platform
that doesn't use manipulative algorithms
and which lets me quickly see how news
outlets around the world are covering a
story. Ground News helps me get a
snapshot of the entire media ecosystem,
left, right, and center, which I found
really useful as someone who's scanning
the internet all day. I found Ground
News to be particularly helpful when I
was trying to parse through Donald
Trump's massive legislative agenda. On
the left, ground news surfaced an
American Prospect article called 10
bizarre things hidden in Trump's big
beautiful bill. In the center, it also
surfaced a great analysis from Higher Ed
Drive called One Big Mistake: Higher Ed
Sounds Warning Over GOP Budget Law. And
then I also was able to find a bunch of
news takes and analysis from right-wing
outlets without having to dive into the
muck on X. Ground News let me do all
that research really seamlessly without
having to endlessly scroll through
social media's echo chamber reinforcing
algorithms. Go to groundnews.com/media
today to get 40% off the Ground News
Vantage Plan and get access to all of
their news analysis features. That's
groundnews.com/media
for 40% off the Ground News Vantage Plan
for a limited time only.
groundnews.com/media.

Hello and welcome to the 404 media
podcast where we bring you unparalleled

IRL. 404 media is a journalist founded
company and needs your support. To
subscribe, go to 404media.co
as well as bonus content every single
week. Subscribers also get access to
additional episodes where we respond to
the best comments. gain access to that
content at 404media.co.
I'm your host, Joseph, and with me are
404 media co-founders, Sam Cole.
Hello.
And Emanuel Mayberg.
Hello. Jason's not here. He's still on
vacation. We, as listeners will know, we
all took last week off, which is only
possible due to our paying subscribers.
We have never done that since we
launched in August 2023. At this point,
uh, it was rejuvenating and ready to get
back into it. A ton of stories already
to go through now and then we're going
to have a bunch more for next week um,
as well. So, let's get straight into it.
This first one is one that Emanuel
published uh, I think today or or
yesterday. The open-source software
saving the internet from AI bot
scrapers. So we spoke about the problem
a little bit on an earlier um episode of
the podcast. Can you just lay out that
problem first of all before we talk
about this solution? So what is
happening with AI scrapers and who is it
impacting exactly?
I think uh one of the funny things about
taking a vacation after not doing it for
so long is it warps your perception of
time. And I'm like when did we have that
podcast? Was that two weeks ago or the
early 90s? I don't remember. But yeah,
it was like I think it was two weeks
ago. Um I wrote this story about the
first good study that I've seen about
how AI
uh training data scrapers are really
messing with libraries, museums, and any
other form of uh resource or archive
that's open to the public. So you have
all these AI companies. They need all
the training data they can get in order
to train their AI models. So they send
these bots to crawl the entire web and
hoover up all that data. And there are
so many companies doing this now. And
they're doing it so rapidly that if
you're just a a university or even a big
university with an online library, all
these bots suddenly hit your website.
They're doing it millions of times a day
and they crash the websites eventually
uh making them unavailable for the human
users that they were initially made for.
So that's kind of largely the problem.
Yeah. They're being bombarded basically
in these maybe not intentional but
essentially DOS attacks where there's
all of this traffic coming and and it's
knocking these systems offline so nobody
can really uh enjoy or read them or get
anything from them. So that's the
problem. You need some sort of solution,
some sort of mitigation. I mean
hopefully the mitigation isn't take them
offline which uh some people have
unfortunately had to do. So enter this
tool that you've just written about
called Anubis. What is it and you know
how does it work? How's it trying to
address this problem? So I wrote that
story that I just talked about and a
bunch of people reached out and said,
"Hey, you should really check out
Anubis. There are several solutions that
people are trying in order to prevent
these uh AI uh bots. One that we've
talked about and that historically has
worked is robots txt, which is a file
you can put in front of your website
that tells uh bots not to crawl it. Just
like no automated tools should crawl
this website. That used to work. That
was pre the generative AI boom and this
data mining gold rush. Suddenly people
just don't give a and they're like
scraping the sites anyway. So yeah, go
ahead.
Is is that the reason it doesn't work?
Because again, you're totally right and
plenty of people have brought this up
that it used to work pretty effectively.
You you you have that file on your
website and it tells people please don't
scrape this. Uh is it just that people
don't care now or there's like way more
people doing scraping or a combination
of both? Like why doesn't robots work
anymore?
Because it's not a rule. You know what I
mean? It's not like if you ignore
robots.txt the internet police is going
to come to your house and arrest you. It
just
what?
Not yet.
Not yet. Once they give us badges, maybe
we will do it. But uh no, it's it's it's
it's just a norm that used to be
respected. And I don't know, we should
probably talk about this at some point,
but the internet used to there's
protocols and there's norms. And the
internet used to to run on a lot of
norms. And these are just being ignored
entirely now because it's going to be
very profitable for you to build a
successful AI tool. So if you need to
jump over the robots.txt TXT fence in
order to get that training data. You're
going to do it. Who cares? Um, so that
no longer works. You have some other big
companies that are trying things. Uh,
Cloudflare, I think they announced a new
method that they're trying today where
they're blocking AI bots by default. I'm
not sure how exactly that works. They've
also done this kind of mischievous thing
where uh Jason wrote about this, some
other people are doing this, but once
you uh once an AI bot comes to your
site, you kind of send it down a rabbit
hole of neverending links to garbage
websites and you kind of trap it in this
infinite loop. Uh so that's one
solution.
Anubis
is the reason people I think reached out
to me and are very happy with it and
it's getting widely adopted is it's
lightweight, it's open source and it's
fairly effective
um in a in a less expensive
way that we can get into later.
Yeah. Um, and I think the Cloudflare one
as well. I mean, hate to hand it to

ideologation
or whatever. Oh, okay. Dash did

potentially through that Cloudflare

to well do you want to pay this
publisher to script this material
right?
Yeah. So, you you asked me how it works,
which I I I lightly dodge because it's
complicated and I don't want to get it
wrong, but basically
these bots, the scrapers that are
trolling the entire internet, they don't
look or behave like a normal internet
user. When that traffic comes to a
website, it doesn't look like a human
user who is using a browser in order to
access the website because there's no
browser involved. It's just like a very
lightweight automated tool that is
accessing the site and taking the data.
What Anubis does is basically put a
check before you can access the site
where it is looking for a type of um
uh uh cryptography that JavaScript does
and has been doing and all web all web
browsers have been doing uh since around
2022. Uh maybe you could talk about this
a little bit. A lot of people really
hate JavaScript and there are browsers
that don't use it and there are people
who kind of disable JavaScript across
the board. So if you're one of those
people, you're not going to be able to
access sites that use Anubis. But the
vast majority of people are using Chrome
or some other type of browser that is
constantly
going through this cryptographic check
to make sure that the user is there and
that they're they're using a browser.
And basically all Anubis does is look
for that once it verifies
um that it's a that it's a browser that
it's probably a human and it lets you
through. Uh the reason that is clever is
because uh there's a cat and mouse game
that's happening between uh admins and
people that that are trying to protect
our websites from scrapers and the AI
companies. So the reason that the
creator of Anubis uh Shi Yaso was
willing to tell me how this check works
is because she knows that the AI
companies can't really implement the
solution. It would be too
computationally expensive for all these
AI scrapers to pretend to run Chrome
before they access a website. And that's
why it's kind of like a simple,
lightweight, clever solution.
Yeah, it is really smart. Um, and I
don't want to oversimplify it, but maybe
it's just a way for people to
understand, but like, you know, it's a
more sophisticated capture in a way
where a capture is, you know, you're
you're doing proof that you're not a
robot, you're solving a little puzzle.
Of course, there are entire
companies of people in various countries
who will get commissioned. uh I think
commission is putting it very
charitably. They'll be paid very very
low wages to click through captures and
then provide the solution to that and of
course a plenty of AIs can actually
bypass captures. Now this is like a much
smarter way of going about it. Um it
seems and you mentioned JavaScript and
I'll just say briefly like it seems like
a really good trade-off to me that you
know you have this JavaScript running in
your browser you're using ordinary web
browser it lets you through. You're
right in that some people don't like to
use it. For example, when you download
the tour browser, there is a a very easy
to flick on and off setting to disable
or enable JavaScript. And the reason for
that is, you know, you can leak some

websites are running certain pieces of
code. And you know, it's I I guess it's
a little bit less now, but you go even 5
6 7 years ago, malvertising was just a

constantly used to deliver malware to

rap, but I don't know, you're an
ordinary user with a fully upto-date
um uh web browser and you're accessing a
website. Seems like a pretty good

really. So, you mentioned you spoke to
the creator. Um, what did they tell you

Like, what makes somebody wake up and
then just go, I'm going to make a new
scrapers came for her. That's why she

to make Anubis.
That's amazing. So she makes it it
sounds like for for personal use
initially. Uh did she uh upload it

people I'm I'm just trying to get from
how she makes it to apparently a ton of

the what happens in between those two

Yeah, I think it's just word of mouth.
She did make it available. It was on

then a bunch of people in the open

um and then yeah it's been downloaded
when I wrote the story it was 200,000

UNESCO's

some universities use it you sent me a

Yeah, I'm trying to find it right now um

protecting uh our property and
protecting us from scrapers. And it
seems like it it worked um pretty well.
Yeah. And and I guess like just to

or CIS admins is a lot of people, I
would say.
Yeah. Yeah. Two. Yeah. Right. It's It's
individual users and their little blogs.
It's 200,000 users, many of which are uh
the admins of incredibly valuable
uh online resources that are accessed by
millions and millions and of people.
Yeah. So I guess just the last thing is
what do you think happens now? Is it
just that more and more people use

solutions start cropping up like cloud
flares as well and there's just sort of
this ecosystem of all of these hey screw
you stop scraping us solutions.
Yeah, I think it's hard to imagine
that Cloudflare is not going to provide

infrastructure companies are probably
going to do the same.
I think the question is how popular this
open- source alternative gets. And I
don't know the answer to that, but I
know that it has a lot of momentum. I
know that a lot of people are uh using

The developer says that she's not yet at

open-source
protocol that is very popular and is
used more and more as this problem

Yeah, the problem isn't going away and

Yeah, that's fair. And I guess the last

a big reason why we require email

the way that we can see that is a a

All right, we are back with one of Joe's
stories. Uh the headline is ICE is using
a new facial recognition app to identify
people leaked emails show. Um, so Joe,
you've been doing a ton of really good
reporting about ICE and about facial
recognitions separately and sometimes
combined.
Um, this to me is something that was not
even on my radar yet as far as what
police were doing in the field and then
realizing that they were sticking phones
in people's faces and then also using
that as a facial recognition app was
just like a one, two, like, oh my god,
this is insane and horrible. Um, so
yeah, why don't you just explain maybe
for a second before we dive into the app
itself? U for people who might not be
familiar, what exactly are police doing
or ICE agents or officers or whoever
doing in the field that people were
like, "Oh what are they doing?
What are they doing with their phones
before we get into the app even?"
Yeah. Yeah, that's fair. So, um, as many
listeners will know, ICE is conducting
operations all around the United States,
but especially in Los Angeles. Um, and
of course, there were protests in
response to that and Trump deployed in
the National Guard and then later the
Marines. Um those protests have kind of
peted out for the moment, but there are
all of these sort of individual flash
points where ICE will raid a Home Depot
or a 7-Eleven or somewhere else and then
the community will get around it. Um ICE
will be wearing masks. They'll be
heavily armed. They may not identify
what agency they're from, uh their badge
number or anything like that. And
there's a few videos coming out around
that time of ICE officers repeatedly
taking their mobile phones and sort of
not shining or almost shoving them into
people's faces like very deliberately
and clearly filming or taking a photo of
people. And there was one very stark
example where a protester was following
ICE in his vehicle. From the video that
was published, it didn't look like he
was interfering with the operation. It
didn't look like he was getting in the
way of federal law enforcement or
anything like that, but he was following
them. These apparent ICE officers stop.
They get out of their vehicle. They
crowd around his car, and this is like
it seems on a busy uh road. They then
start asking him, "What are you doing?
Why are you following us?" and then two
maybe three of them get out their phones
and keep pointing it at his face. Like
it looks like they're taking photos of
his face. And that's what I thought it
was at the time. And it might still be
and we'll get into the nuances of what
exactly we know and what we don't know.
Um, but people saw that and they were
asking on social media and and
elsewhere, why is ICE, why do they keep
taking photos um of us, which I know a
fair question to to ask, but then I got
these leaked emails from Inside ICE
revealing the agency has a new facial
recognition app. So maybe they're using
that. We don't know if in all of these
videos um they're doing that, but it
absolutely adds new context to that. And
the fact is that ICE does have this app
now, as you know, I'm sure we'll get
into.
Yeah. So, what is this app, like you
said, might or might not be what is in
the videos. We don't know, but we know
that it's being used or at least Ice has
it. Um what's it called and what does it
promise to do? Yeah. So, it's called
Mobile Fortify,
and it promises to allow ICE agents to
identify people in the field by simply
pointing their mobile phone um at them,
which
obviously is the point of facial
recognition. That's obviously the entire
purpose of the technology. But it's one
thing to have facial recognition, I
don't know, on a camera outside a
military base to make sure who's coming
in or, you know, facial recognition at a
real a retail store, which is still very
controversial. But it's different to
have it immediately and accessible in
the hands of federal law enforcement who
are grabbing people
without due process and putting them
into this blackbox system and giving
them a capability right into the palm of
their hands that can identify people um
on on the street. And we've of course
ICE has facial recognition from other
companies uh as well. Well, we don't
know who made this one, whether it's
in-house or or made by somebody else and
other law enforcement do as well, but
it's it's the immediaccy and it's
definitely the context of Trump's mass
deportations that makes this
interesting. And of course, these emails
um that I got, ICE was announcing the
existence and the availability of this
app to all of the personnel in
enforcement and and removal operations,
ERO. And that's a part of ICE that you
know that deals with deportations. This
isn't HSI which does child abuse
investigations. This is erro the
deportation part of ICE.
Okay. Gotcha. So you found this through
FOYA documents or how did you figure out
the details of this app?
I was leaked emails from inside
Oh leaked. Okay. from inside ICE and
these emails were sent to all personnel
inside um ERRO. So that's a very
widespread of people which I think is
interesting because that's a very
widespread of people that may or uh may
or may not be using this tool. It's at
least being advertised to them inside um
the agency. And of course with this new

passed and then Trump's, you know,
signed into law, ICE just got another 6
billion for surveillance capabilities
and I think 150 overall, 45 for um more
uh facilities to store people, all of
that sort of thing. Um so it's clear
they're ramping up their surveillance um
tech. And I think this is just one one
part of it.
Yeah. Okay. Gotcha. Yeah. Sending it to
everyone in ERO is very very crazy. So
we know that like Clear View as you
mentioned before um uses facial
recognition tech, but how is this
similar? How is different? Is it
different? Um what are we working with
here in comparison since we already have
that as kind of like a an example?
Yeah. So the way that facial recognition
tech works really broadly and obviously
there'll be some differences between
different companies and that sort of
thing but broadly is that it has this
massive database of images of people's
faces or maybe it has a massive database
of the hashes of people's faces like the
cryptographic uh representation of it
but a lot of the time it's just going to
be literal photos. That's the case with
clear view AI which is a company that
Kashmir Hill and your times revealed
several years ago at this point and they
had as she described in that coverage
and as the the person who provided the
public records to her they had sort of
crossed the Rubicon of facial
recognition where to build that database
of faces clear view scraped social media
it scraped the web so people's Venmo
accounts
uh social media accounts, uh web pages,
all this sort of thing, and created this
massive database of billions upon
billions um of faces. Um that's what
makes Clear View apparently pretty
powerful and apparently very popular
with law enforcement at a local, state,
and federal level. So, that's how it
usually works and that's how you usually
get this sort of data. with this new ICE
app um mobile Fortify. It's not using
images scraped from social media. Well,
it appears to be using and again there
are still there are still questions we
don't have all of the answers to, but
it's the emails I've got said this ICE
app is using the system from Customs and
Border Protection that takes a photo of
somebody every time they enter or leave
the United States. you imagine you go to
the border and that could be uh you know
LA airport or whatever or it could be
crossing uh via car from Mexico or
wherever you're probably almost
certainly going to have your photo taken
especially if you're you know on a
travel visa or or a work visa or
something like that your photo will be
taken. Now, the emails again aren't
particularly
um
they they they don't answer all of the
questions, but here's one quote which I
thought was very very telling. The app
uses CBP's traveler verification service
and the seizure and apprehends
the biometric gallery of individual for
individuals for whom CBP maintains
derogatory information for f facial
recognition. There's a lot of buzzwords
in there. Derogatory comes up and
they're sometimes hard to tell what they
mean, but they say they have a biometric

If you like 404 Media, you probably have followed our reporting about how big tech has made consuming the news a mess. Social media and search algorithms have made finding and understanding the news exhausting. It's tough scrolling through timelines full of content that have been reverse engineered to perform well in an algorithm or that you're only seeing because of targeted advertising. That's why I like Ground News, a news platform that doesn't use manipulative algorithms and which lets me quickly see how news outlets around the world are covering a story. Ground News helps me get a snapshot of the entire media ecosystem, left, right, and center, which I found really useful as someone who's scanning the internet all day. I found Ground News to be particularly helpful when I was trying to parse through Donald Trump's massive legislative agenda. On the left, Ground News surfaced an American Prospect article called "10 bizarre things hidden in Trump's big beautiful bill." In the center, it also surfaced a great analysis from Higher Ed Drive called "One Big Mistake: Higher Ed Sounds Warning Over GOP Budget Law." And then I also was able to find a bunch of news takes and analysis from right-wing outlets without having to dive into the muck on X. Ground News let me do all that research really seamlessly without having to endlessly scroll through social media's echo chamber reinforcing algorithms. Go to groundnews.com/media today to get 40% off the Ground News Vantage Plan and get access to all of their news analysis features. That's groundnews.com/media for 40% off the Ground News Vantage Plan for a limited time only. groundnews.com/media.

To subscribe, go to 404media.co as well as bonus content every single week. Subscribers also get access to additional episodes where we respond to the best comments. Gain access to that content at 404media.co.

I'm your host, Joseph, and with me are 404 Media co-founders, Sam Cole.

Hello.

And Emanuel Mayberg.

Hello.

Jason's not here. He's still on vacation. We, as listeners will know, we all took last week off, which is only possible due to our paying subscribers. We have never done that since we launched in August 2023. At this point, uh, it was rejuvenating and ready to get back into it. A ton of stories already to go through now and then we're going to have a bunch more for next week um, as well. So, let's get straight into it. This first one is one that Emanuel published uh, I think today or or yesterday. The open-source software saving the internet from AI bot scrapers. So we spoke about the problem a little bit on an earlier um episode of the podcast. Can you just lay out that problem first of all before we talk about this solution? So what is happening with AI scrapers and who is it impacting exactly?

I think uh one of the funny things about taking a vacation after not doing it for so long is it warps your perception of time. And I'm like when did we have that podcast? Was that two weeks ago or the early 90s? I don't remember. But yeah, it was like I think it was two weeks ago. Um I wrote this story about the first good study that I've seen about how AI uh training data scrapers are really messing with libraries, museums, and any other form of uh resource or archive that's open to the public. So you have all these AI companies. They need all the training data they can get in order to train their AI models. So they send these bots to crawl the entire web and hoover up all that data. And there are so many companies doing this now. And they're doing it so rapidly that if you're just a a university or even a big university with an online library, all these bots suddenly hit your website. They're doing it millions of times a day and they crash the websites eventually uh making them unavailable for the human users that they were initially made for. So that's kind of largely the problem.

Yeah. They're being bombarded basically in these maybe not intentional but essentially DOS attacks where there's all of this traffic coming and and it's knocking these systems offline so nobody can really uh enjoy or read them or get anything from them. So that's the problem. You need some sort of solution, some sort of mitigation. I mean hopefully the mitigation isn't take them offline which uh some people have unfortunately had to do. So enter this tool that you've just written about called Anubis. What is it and you know how does it work? How's it trying to address this problem? So I wrote that story that I just talked about and a bunch of people reached out and said, "Hey, you should really check out Anubis. There are several solutions that people are trying in order to prevent these uh AI uh bots. One that we've talked about and that historically has worked is robots.txt, which is a file you can put in front of your website that tells uh bots not to crawl it. Just like no automated tools should crawl this website. That used to work. That was pre the generative AI boom and this data mining gold rush. Suddenly people just don't give a and they're like scraping the sites anyway. So yeah, go ahead.

Is is that the reason it doesn't work? Because again, you're totally right and plenty of people have brought this up that it used to work pretty effectively. You you you have that file on your website and it tells people please don't scrape this. Uh is it just that people don't care now or there's like way more people doing scraping or a combination of both? Like why doesn't robots work anymore?

Because it's not a rule. You know what I mean? It's not like if you ignore robots.txt the internet police is going to come to your house and arrest you. It just what?

Not yet.

Not yet. Once they give us badges, maybe we will do it. But uh no, it's it's it's just a norm that used to be respected. And I don't know, we should probably talk about this at some point, but the internet used to there's protocols and there's norms. And the internet used to to run on a lot of norms. And these are just being ignored entirely now because it's going to be very profitable for you to build a successful AI tool. So if you need to jump over the robots.txt TXT fence in order to get that training data. You're going to do it. Who cares? Um, so that no longer works. You have some other big companies that are trying things. Uh, Cloudflare, I think they announced a new method that they're trying today where they're blocking AI bots by default. I'm not sure how exactly that works. They've also done this kind of mischievous thing where uh Jason wrote about this, some other people are doing this, but once you uh once an AI bot comes to your site, you kind of send it down a rabbit hole of neverending links to garbage websites and you kind of trap it in this infinite loop. Uh so that's one solution.

Anubis is the reason people I think reached out to me and are very happy with it and it's getting widely adopted is it's lightweight, it's open source and it's fairly effective um in a in a less expensive way that we can get into later.

Yeah. Um, and I think the Cloudflare one as well. I mean, hate to hand it to Cloudflare, a company that enables a lot of bad stuff and it's kind of all over the place when it comes to his ideologation or whatever. Oh, okay. Dash did something pretty interesting. I'll give them that. Um, but there's also a way that publishers may be able to get funds potentially through that Cloudflare mechanism as well. It will direct people to well do you want to pay this publisher to script this material right?

Yeah. So, you you asked me how it works, which I I I lightly dodge because it's complicated and I don't want to get it wrong, but basically these bots, the scrapers that are trolling the entire internet, they don't look or behave like a normal internet user. When that traffic comes to a website, it doesn't look like a human user who is using a browser in order to access the website because there's no browser involved. It's just like a very lightweight automated tool that is accessing the site and taking the data. What Anubis does is basically put a check before you can access the site where it is looking for a type of um uh uh cryptography that JavaScript does and has been doing and all web all web browsers have been doing uh since around 2022. Uh maybe you could talk about this a little bit. A lot of people really hate JavaScript and there are browsers that don't use it and there are people who kind of disable JavaScript across the board. So if you're one of those people, you're not going to be able to access sites that use Anubis. But the vast majority of people are using Chrome or some other type of browser that is constantly going through this cryptographic check to make sure that the user is there and that they're they're using a browser. And basically all Anubis does is look for that once it verifies um that it's a that it's a browser that it's probably a human and it lets you through. Uh the reason that is clever is because uh there's a cat and mouse game that's happening between uh admins and people that that are trying to protect our websites from scrapers and the AI companies. So the reason that the creator of Anubis uh Shi Yaso was willing to tell me how this check works is because she knows that the AI companies can't really implement the solution. It would be too computationally expensive for all these AI scrapers to pretend to run Chrome before they access a website. And that's why it's kind of like a simple, lightweight, clever solution.

Yeah, it is really smart. Um, and I don't want to oversimplify it, but maybe it's just a way for people to understand, but like, you know, it's a more sophisticated capture in a way where a capture is, you know, you're you're doing proof that you're not a robot, you're solving a little puzzle. Of course, there are entire companies of people in various countries who will get commissioned. uh I think commission is putting it very charitably. They'll be paid very very low wages to click through captures and then provide the solution to that and of course a plenty of AIs can actually bypass captures. Now this is like a much smarter way of going about it. Um it seems and you mentioned JavaScript and I'll just say briefly like it seems like a really good trade-off to me that you know you have this JavaScript running in your browser you're using ordinary web browser it lets you through. You're right in that some people don't like to use it. For example, when you download the tour browser, there is a a very easy to flick on and off setting to disable or enable JavaScript. And the reason for that is, you know, you can leak some personal data about your device to websites are running certain pieces of code. And you know, it's I I guess it's a little bit less now, but you go even 5 6 7 years ago, malvertising was just a massive thing where JavaScript was constantly used to deliver malware to people's devices simply for loading a web page. So, it doesn't have the best rap, but I don't know, you're an ordinary user with a fully upto-date um uh web browser and you're accessing a website. Seems like a pretty good trade-off to filter out all the AI bots really. So, you mentioned you spoke to the creator. Um, what did they tell you about why they decided to make this?

Like, what makes somebody wake up and then just go, I'm going to make a new scrapers came for her. That's why she did it. Uh, like all the other libraries and archives that were in this previous story that I I wrote about how AI scrapers are messing up their infrastructure, she has a git server where she keeps some of her work. She keeps it open so other people can access it. And one day she was trying to access it. It didn't it didn't work. And she looked at what was going on and some kind of Amazon AI scraper was hitting it hundreds and hundreds of times and uh forcing it to reset and then eventually go offline and that's when she set out to make Anubis.

That's amazing. So she makes it it sounds like for for personal use initially. Uh did she uh upload it publicly at the same time and then people I'm I'm just trying to get from how she makes it to apparently a ton of people are now using this like what's the what happens in between those two points?

Yeah, I think it's just word of mouth. She did make it available. It was on GitHub and I think people started to use it and it seems like what really made it take off is that uh I know that you're previously a Linux user so maybe you're familiar with this but Gnome which is a popular open-source uh implementation of Linux started to use it to kind of protect its libraries and all of its publicly available data. they picked it up and it kind of went from there and then a bunch of people in the open source community honestly started to use it because it is open source I think was part of the attraction um and then yeah it's been downloaded when I wrote the story it was 200,000 times I imagine it's a lot higher now because the story got some pickup and people were really excited about it uh UNESCO's uh website and infrastructure uses it uh some universities use it you sent me a story after I published where Duke had a case study about them dealing with scrapers and they also came to Anubis for the solution. I think that's what they ended up doing.

Yeah, I'm trying to find it right now um about remember off the top of my head in that it wasn't even just that they were using it. They were like almost reviewing it and being like this is how effective this was um for you know protecting uh our property and protecting us from scrapers. And it seems like it it worked um pretty well.

Yeah. And and I guess like just to stress like 200,000 people downloading something, okay, not the biggest number in the world, but like they're not random normal users. They're probably web administrators or something, you know, like that. And 200,000 web admins or CIS admins is a lot of people, I would say.

Yeah. Yeah. Two. Yeah. Right. It's It's not 200,000 individual users and their little blogs. It's 200,000 users, many of which are uh the admins of incredibly valuable uh online resources that are accessed by millions and millions and of people.

Yeah. So I guess just the last thing is what do you think happens now? Is it just that more and more people use Anubis or is it also I mean


Obviously, both can be true. Maybe more and more solutions start cropping up like cloud flares as well, and there's just sort of this ecosystem of all of these, "Hey, screw you, stop scraping us" solutions.
Yeah, I think it's hard to imagine that Cloudflare is not going to provide some sort of workable solution to its customer base, and other internet infrastructure companies are probably going to do the same.
I think the question is how popular this open-source alternative gets. And I don't know the answer to that, but I know that it has a lot of momentum. I know that a lot of people are using it. A lot of notable organizations are using it.
The developer says that she's not yet at a place where it can be her full-time job, but she wants it to be. Uh, and I don't know. I can definitely imagine that happening. I can imagine her getting enough donations to make this a full-time job, hire a contributor, and have it be like an open-source protocol that is very popular and is used more and more as this problem persists.
Yeah, the problem isn't going away, and it's probably not even getting smaller or plateauing. It's going to get worse if anything. And the other thing I forgot to mention is that not everyone can or wants to use Cloudflare or another kind of solution from a big company. A lot of people on principle or for practical reasons want an open-source free solution.
Yeah, that's fair. And I guess the last thing I'll say is, um, of course, we try to block AI scrapers as well. This is a big reason why we require email address signups on the site. You know, an article will go out there, and we'll pull it behind the free wall where you have to provide the email, and you know, and then stuff is obviously payable as well. But it seems that it has stopped some scraping, and the way that we can see that is a fewer AI generator ripoffs of our articles essentially, which is not the best metric in the world, but it's a pretty good one, and I'm sure we'll look deeper into it as well of how much are being scraped and whether it's going down or plateauing or whatever. Um, but that's what we do. All right, we'll leave that there, and when we come back, we're going to talk about another story of mine, which is about ICE and its new facial recognition app.
We'll be right back after this.

All right, we are back with one of Joseph's stories. Uh, the headline is ICE is using a new facial recognition app to identify people, leaked emails show. Um, so Joseph, you've been doing a ton of really good reporting about ICE and about facial recognition separately and sometimes combined.
Um, this to me is something that was not even on my radar yet as far as what police were doing in the field and then realizing that they were sticking phones in people's faces and then also using that as a facial recognition app was just like a one, two, like, "Oh my god, this is insane and horrible." Um, so yeah, why don't you just explain maybe for a second before we dive into the app itself? For people who might not be familiar, what exactly are police doing or ICE agents or officers or whoever doing in the field that people were like, "Oh, what are they doing? What are they doing with their phones before we get into the app even?"
Yeah. Yeah, that's fair. So, um, as many listeners will know, ICE is conducting operations all around the United States, but especially in Los Angeles. Um, and of course, there were protests in response to that, and Trump deployed the National Guard and then later the Marines. Um, those protests have kind of petered out for the moment, but there are all of these sort of individual flashpoints where ICE will raid a Home Depot or a 7-Eleven or somewhere else, and then the community will get around it. Um, ICE will be wearing masks. They'll be heavily armed. They may not identify what agency they're from, uh, their badge number or anything like that. And there's a few videos coming out around that time of ICE officers repeatedly taking their mobile phones and sort of not shining or almost shoving them into people's faces, like very deliberately and clearly filming or taking a photo of people. And there was one very stark example where a protester was following ICE in his vehicle. From the video that was published, it didn't look like he was interfering with the operation. It didn't look like he was getting in the way of federal law enforcement or anything like that, but he was following them. These apparent ICE officers stop. They get out of their vehicle. They crowd around his car, and this is like it seems on a busy road. They then start asking him, "What are you doing? Why are you following us?" and then two, maybe three of them get out their phones and keep pointing it at his face. Like it looks like they're taking photos of his face. And that's what I thought it was at the time. And it might still be, and we'll get into the nuances of what exactly we know and what we don't know. Um, but people saw that, and they were asking on social media and elsewhere, why is ICE, why do they keep taking photos of us, which I know a fair question to ask, but then I got these leaked emails from Inside ICE revealing the agency has a new facial recognition app. So maybe they're using that. We don't know if in all of these videos they're doing that, but it absolutely adds new context to that. And the fact is that ICE does have this app now, as you know, I'm sure we'll get into.
Yeah. So, what is this app, like you said, might or might not be what is in the videos. We don't know, but we know that it's being used or at least ICE has it. Um, what's it called and what does it promise to do? Yeah. So, it's called Mobile Fortify, and it promises to allow ICE agents to identify people in the field by simply pointing their mobile phone at them, which obviously is the point of facial recognition. That's obviously the entire purpose of the technology. But it's one thing to have facial recognition, I don't know, on a camera outside a military base to make sure who's coming in or, you know, facial recognition at a retail store, which is still very controversial. But it's different to have it immediately and accessible in the hands of federal law enforcement who are grabbing people without due process and putting them into this black box system and giving them a capability right into the palm of their hands that can identify people on the street. And we've of course ICE has facial recognition from other companies as well. Well, we don't know who made this one, whether it's in-house or made by somebody else, and other law enforcement do as well, but it's the immediacy and it's definitely the context of Trump's mass deportations that makes this interesting. And of course, these emails that I got, ICE was announcing the existence and the availability of this app to all of the personnel in enforcement and removal operations, ERO. And that's a part of ICE that you know that deals with deportations. This isn't HSI which does child abuse investigations. This is ERO, the deportation part of ICE.
Okay. Gotcha. So you found this through FOIA documents or how did you figure out the details of this app?
I was leaked emails from inside.
Oh, leaked. Okay. From inside ICE, and these emails were sent to all personnel inside ERO. So that's a very widespread of people, which I think is interesting because that's a very widespread of people that may or may not be using this tool. It's at least being advertised to them inside the agency. And of course, with this new budget that US lawmakers have just passed and then Trump's, you know, signed into law, ICE just got another 6 billion for surveillance capabilities and I think 150 overall, 45 for more facilities to store people, all of that sort of thing. Um, so it's clear they're ramping up their surveillance tech. And I think this is just one part of it.
Yeah. Okay. Gotcha. Yeah. Sending it to everyone in ERO is very, very crazy. So we know that like Clearview as you mentioned before uses facial recognition tech, but how is this similar? How is different? Is it different? Um, what are we working with here in comparison since we already have that as kind of like an example?
Yeah. So the way that facial recognition tech works really broadly, and obviously there'll be some differences between different companies and that sort of thing, but broadly is that it has this massive database of images of people's faces or maybe it has a massive database of the hashes of people's faces, like the cryptographic representation of it, but a lot of the time it's just going to be literal photos. That's the case with Clearview AI, which is a company that Kashmir Hill and your times revealed several years ago at this point, and they had, as she described in that coverage and as the person who provided the public records to her, they had sort of crossed the Rubicon of facial recognition where to build that database of faces, Clearview scraped social media, it scraped the web, so people's Venmo accounts, uh, social media accounts, uh, web pages, all this sort of thing, and created this massive database of billions upon billions of faces. Um, that's what makes Clearview apparently pretty powerful and apparently very popular with law enforcement at a local, state, and federal level. So, that's how it usually works, and that's how you usually get this sort of data. With this new ICE app, Mobile Fortify, it's not using images scraped from social media. Well, it appears to be using, and again, there are still, there are still questions, we don't have all of the answers to, but it's the emails I've got said this ICE app is using the system from Customs and Border Protection that takes a photo of somebody every time they enter or leave the United States. You imagine you go to the border, and that could be LA airport or whatever, or it could be crossing via car from Mexico or wherever, you're probably almost certainly going to have your photo taken, especially if you're, you know, on a travel visa or or a work visa or something like that, your photo will be taken. Now, the emails again aren't particularly, um, they, they, they don't answer all of the questions, but here's one quote which I thought was very, very telling.
